lg.l: At Christchurch, Christchurch. The main settlement in the Canterbury region, situated approximately five kilometres from the area known as Papanui Bush, one of the only areas of forest in the vicinity. at the dawn of day,
All mudless stood the unloaded dray; Unloaded dray. Bullock (ox) wagons were used to haul timber from Papanui to Christchurch, and the forest was largely destroyed by 1857.
And in the stockyard, near it, lay
Eight bullocks, waiting patiently.
The driver thought it not so nice,
That afternoon, when clocks struck twice,

Plunging in swamps Plunging in swamps. The area at this time “consisted chiefly of an almost impassable swamp, practically bottomless, for the purposes of the teamster” (Cyclopedia of New Zealand, 1903). and mud-stained ice,
The deepness of the axle-tree.
In slush and quagmire fast as nails
The oxen wag their muddy tails;
But furious still the driver flails
And double-thongs Double-thongs. To whip the bullocks with a whip made of two plaited strands of leather. unceasingly.
Then plunge the steers to anger driven,
Then cracks the pole with plunges riven;
And, louder than these noises even,
Loud cracks the whip discordantly.
But heavier yet that whip must drop
On mud-stuck oxen, neck and crop;
And longer yet that dray must stop,
Imbedded to its axle-tree.
‘Tis road; Road. The road to Papanui was one of the first to be built beyond the boundaries of Christchurch but was not paved until 1857. but scarce the sharpest one
Can see the work that once was done,
Where drains across the causeway run,
Mixed to a thin consistency.
The quagmire thickens; on ye pack!
Through slimy swamps and spongy track.
Crack, driver, all thy whipcord crack,
And shout with all thy ribaldry. Ribaldry. Bullock drivers were infamous for the coarse language they directed towards their animals.
Few, few will cart, such holes to meet!
Each swamp will lower the price of wheat;
And every road be called a feat
Of Government perversity.
